entries.title: Google GeoChart, JSON and Perl
entries.text: Although the example published by Johnny Morano uses CGI, it can help you get started with the creation of a chart showing the earth and displaying the countries with different colors.

entries.title: Oozing Caribou
entries.text: Oozie is a workflow scheduler for Hadoop that defines its workflows using a horrific XML dialect. Yanick Champoux took his Template::Caribou for a ride to make the XML behave.

entries.title: Underappreciated Perl Code: TAP's YAMLish Syntax
entries.text: Parsing the error messages from a test script might be difficult as those include free text and were designed to be read by humans, not by computers. OTOH if you can get a well formatted version of this output then it will be possible and even easy to write a parser for them. This is what came out of the Wumpus Cave of Timm Murray.

entries.title: Software Test Podcast
entries.text: I did not have time to listen to the actual podcast yet, but what David Cantrell writes about the distinction between Quality Control and Quality Assurance is interesting.

entries.title: CPAN Testers Summary - Oct 2013 - What's THIS For...!
entries.text: There was a big server upgrade that went well with only a few hickups. Of course the server is not free. You can read how it is being financed.

entries.title: Perl 5 Internals - Part Four
entries.text: In this part of the series, Rob Hoelz covers the optree, which is quite similar to what others might call an abstract syntax tree (AST). comments

entries.title: Perl::Critic for the Camel
entries.text: Tom Christiansen started discussing the idea to create a set of Perl::Critic rules that will cover the recommendations of the Camel book (aka. Programming Perl). In case you don't know, Perl::Critic is the implementation of the recommendation from the book 'Perl Best Practices' written by Damian Conway. It is extendable and can server as a great tool to make sure your code follows recommended practices.

entries.title: Released Perl ptkdb debugger to experimental
entries.text: Thanks to Dominique Dumont, Debian and thus Ubuntu are going to get a new version of the Devel::ptkdb debugger.

entries.title: Lintian 2.5.19
entries.text: Niels Thykier has recently released a new, and much faster version of autodie and now Lintian. autodie will turns silent errors into an exception, and Lintian is a Lint-like tool for Debian packages. It tries to find bugs and policy violations.

entries.title: Real $VERSIONs on CPAN
entries.text: Do you know how should a version number on CPAN look like? Not? Don't worry. Apparently there are a few other people who have very interesting ideas about how version numbers should look like.

entries.title: Five percent of indexed CPAN packages come from just two distributions
entries.text: Apparently David Golden was on a roll checking CPAN. What is totally unclear to me is why do those two distribution need so many packages (modules)?

entries.title: NQP gets MoarVM support, cursor reduction, and other news
entries.text: Jonathan Worthington offers another peek into the labs of Perl 6.

entries.title: Setting up DKIM email signatures with Perl
entries.text: DKIM is one of the tools that you, as a sysadmin, mail server owner can help your users to deliver their e-mail avoiding the spam-filtres and to ensure that others cannot abuse your domain by faking messages being sent from it. DKIM signs the messages on the server so the recepient will be able to verify it really came from a server authorized for the domain.
